Exaggerate: The claim may exaggerate the percentage of COVID-19 cases coming from Chicago by stating that 93% of the cases in the state of Illinois have come from the city.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks sufficient evidence or data to support the assertion that 93% of the COVID-19 cases in Illinois originate from Chicago.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the number of cases in Chicago is disproportionately higher compared to other regions in the state without providing substantial evidence to support this assumption.
Exist alternative explanation: There may be alternative explanations for the higher number of cases in Chicago, such as its population density or testing capacity, which are not addressed in the claim.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the actual data from the Illinois Department of Public Health, which shows that Chicago accounted for about 40% of the state's COVID-19 cases at the time the claim was made, not 93% as stated.
Falters at times: The claim may falter in accurately representing the distribution and concentration of COVID-19 cases in Illinois by overemphasizing the role of Chicago.
Understate: The claim may potentially understate the number of cases in other regions of Illinois by focusing primarily on Chicago.
